comments.commentBody:
I recently saw a kids' play where one little girl was amazing and adorable -- not a precious show kid, but a ham with a smile that lit up the stage. I leaned over and said to her mom, who is only an acquaintance, "Aren't you proud? She's so great -- are you just bursting with pride?" The mom said, "What I love is how happy she is up there."

I thought that was an excellent response.

Why was the school nurse talking about this to first graders? It seems like an inappropriate topic and that the nurse could be talking to the kids about more basic health things, especially at that age.
If you don't fight, how do you teach your kids to resolve conflict in a relationship?

I'm so proud of you for that talk. I wish more parents would have it, and be able to talk with such openness. It's the kind of talk I'm hoping I've set myself up for with my daughter, now going on 3...we have open discussions about her vulva, that other women have vulvas, that boys/men have penises (and vulvas! she adds--we have room to grow).

The difference is that as a sex educator, I'm used to having these talks. It's easy for me to talk about these things...but I know that's not true for everyone, which is why I hope to eventually expand my practice to teaching parents to be more comfortable with talking about sex with their kids.

I applaud the writer and wish more parents were like her.  Maybe then I'd be out of a job...I'm a sex educator...and too often my talks come too late (which is why I want to expand my practice to teaching parents about talking to kids about sex).

Actually what I read here is that the author is fiercely defending the legitimacy of her new family.  But her son knows he has a biological dad who he loves.  What the author is really trying to do is to get her son to also divorce his dad.

I feel terribly for the poor nurse and wonder how many abusive parents she has to deal with in a typical school year. The fact that the nurse handled Ms. Krischer professionally and with aplomb speaks volumes about her integrity and sensitivity. She must be a wonderful nurse!

I deal with parents all day long and I have a fantasy that about 20% of them spend most of their free time conjuring up novel ways to become further enmeshed with their children, which frequently results in the enmeshed parent(s) attacking anyone who doesn't buy into their dysfunctional family relationships.

I am extremely grateful for the 80% of parents that honor and respect the professionals that help their children grow up. Unfortunately, however, 20% is large enough to ruin someone's day now and again, and it's always unseemly and distasteful when it happens.

If I've learned nothing else about life, it's that most of the time children can settle differences on their own without the constant intervention of helicopter parents such as Ms. Krischer. Next time a conflict arises, try keeping your mouth zipped by counting to 10 or 20 or 3,000 and see if the kids can settle things on their own. You can't be there to "protect" them 24/7 their entire lives and sooner or later they're going to have to learn to work through some of these non-life threatening issues on their own.

Trust your children. They're smarter than you think.

It is simply disgraceful that the authors of some of the comments seem to disparage the integrity, or even the role, of Irving Picard.

The job of Mr. Picard is to try recover for investors --most of them small. After all, as it is usually the case, the small investors were the ones who were left holding the bag for the most part at game over.

Even then, this will only be cents to the dollar given that banks that very much knew that Mr. Madoff did not trade the volumes of securities for his to not be a Ponzi scheme were just declared off-limits by laws made for Wall Street by Wall Street...

Mr. Picard is doing an exemplary job --by suing he is trying to accomplish what real Wall Street Reform would look like. That is, he wants to expose how the game was rigged in favor of the big cats and banksters, and recover for the investors.

Furthermore, Mr. Picard is not being paid a portion of the moneys recovered, but standard hourly fees complemented with a bonus portion (see http://www.time.com/time/business/article/0,8599,1901593,00.html)

Mr. Picard is indeed a hero --how much better this country would be if Mr. Obama had actually disciplined Wall Street!
At the risk of overemphasizing the intellectual soundness of the court's decision: well, duh?
This is great news if it forces them to sell the team !

Many comments express a sympathy for these guys who spent stolen money.  "These guys" are what the SEC calls "qualified investors."  The idea is that they know what they are doing and are responsible for the consequences of their decisions.  It is hard to believe that they had absolutely no idea that something wasn't quite right.  They took the money and spent it.  Tough luck.  Now, it's time to pay the piper.  Sympathy is inappropriate for "these guys."  They spent stolen money and, frankly, I find it very difficult to believe that Madoff is the only guilty culprit in all this.  I think investigators ought to examine every little trail of money out from Madoff with not just "claw" goals in mind.
Any puzzle with PSHAW in it is a winner in my book.

No need to post this, but the XWordInfo link does not appear to be working. Thanks.

Oh, about the puzzle. I found FEELBAD and MYBAD redundant, and not typical of the NYT standards. I remembered Moe HOWARD from somewhere, but my last entry and a bit of a guess was the A in ROTA/NASL. They both date back to the 70's.

I always have to check crosses to see if the Ford minivan is the original AEROSTAR, the WindSTAR, or the FreeSTAR. They are all now "former" products.

These are rather simple puzzles. You may be inclined to apply higher maths to them, but intuitively, they are not difficult.

The six dot matrix can be solved with two dots changed, 3 and 4.

The ten dot matrix can be done with four dots, 3,4, 7, 9.

No equilateral triangles in either. Again, not challenging.

ITTWACP !
(I thought this was a Cute Puzzle)
Well....really, I guess we have our own form of texting in Wordplay: DNF, MHP...
I've never EVER texted (I need to get a life....) but these ones were all familar to me. AND I remember Daniel from his earlier puzzle; WTG Daniel!

Loved the photo, Deb....I have a secret desire to see Japan someday, particularly the traditional parts that look like your photo. Is there anything more beautiful?

@DeadTreeSolver (45) - those made me LOL!!

S.W.A.K......

Seriously....we need to get t-shirts made!

The Thursday Underground Misfits (or sumpthin....)

@Deb, nice to know you're here too (though we can't really gossip about you then hehe)....you're a sweetie and doing a fabulous job!

jrkenti:

I'm standing by the number 60 (of 6 classes), at least for now. I think you've already noticed that picture 2 in your diagram actually has two monochromatic triangles. Picture 5 (2389) does as well (1,4,6 and 1,7,0). Great diagram, by the way: much easier to see and verify than my list of numbers. Worth redoing with corrections.

Paul (28): Your binary method is exactly the way I wrote my program to find the solutions. I just go through the numbers 0 to 1023, and check the corresponding pattern against the list of triangles to avoid. I haven't found the combinatorial rule you're hoping for, or the smarter algorithm that Kalid hoped for in comment #8. I'm just checking all the possibilities. But I generated the list of 15 triangles by hand, which was why I asked the group for confirmation before going any further. It would be simple to check the 5-row triangle if I could find an algorithmic way to generate the list of triangles to check against. Even the 6-row triangle might be feasible. Beyond that, a smarter algorithm will be necessary because the number of combinations grows too quickly.

Some random thoughts on the puzzle:

I thought Milky Way maker was God.

All these theme answers with initials – Are we stuck on yesterday?

Sac flies produce them – Only Martin knows.

SPACEMEN - They are like flying penmen.

WRIGLEY AND COORS – Thank you Michael Black for the nod – I am a Cubs fan and I drink Coors light. Oh, you meant Wrigley and Coors Fields.

LAIRDS – As in Melvin Laird – former Congressman from Wisconsin and Secretary of Defense?

ICICLE – This recalls the time as a boy when I was the one who trimmed the Christmas tree. I loved to string those aluminum foil icicles one by one. Sadly after I had painstakingly finished trimming the tree with all those individual strands hanging nice and straight, the tree fell over. I took everything off and did it all over. That was an early clue how anal compulsive I am.

OH TO BE in England – Suejean is the lucky one!

Sac flies produce them – Only Martin also knows these.

LIMA OR LENTIL – One I chomp and the other I slurp.

ARRIVE – I'm still waiting.

MY BAD – This post?

I really struggled with that MALLET hammer, too -- but I guess you could say that a MALLET is a hammer and a LENTIL is a bean.  But then, a CLAW is not a hammer, but a type of hammer.  Overanalyzing, but Overanalyzers R Us.  I thought QAS was clued cleverly.  Hope we all got our RBIS after our recent sac fly lesson.  Haven't heard the term NYLONS in several decades, not since the garter belt days.  God, I hated those.

I wonder if there's any connection between his low poll numbers and his recent tone-deaf statements about raising taxes on everyone if they're raised for the richest....

Of course, the sleazy way he weaseled into an illegal third term might have something to do with it also!
I liked Bloomberg until he betrayed the will of the people by running for a 3rd term.

I've always loved NY.  For one thing, as we read here, on any given day you can get an argument from 3 out of 4 people about anything you say.  Everywhere else it's "yeah, the weather's great all right."  But not in NYC.

My biggest problem with Bloomberg is that he will defend the worst people in city government. No matter how poor the job, no matter how fiscally irresponsible, he will never call them on the carpet. He's wants to be everybody's friend without holding people accountable!

My grandson, 9, is the son of my stepson to whose mother I was once married. But he's my grandson -- just ask him. He currently has 5 living grandparents of whom 3 are biological. I was  explaining this to someone once and they said "Then you're not really his grandfather." I could only say  that it certainly feels real.
NYC gets exactly what it elected - a loser.  And he spent a fortune to do so.
